Fig 6 Electrodeposition of Bi nanocomposite with MIL-101 derived carbon as gas diffusion layer for CO2 electroreduction with enhanced formate generation Xuetong Liu Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation a Chi Zhang Investigation Data curation a Nuoyan Li Investigation Formal analysis Data curation b Runfeng Li Investigation Formal analysis a Songlin Lei Investigation Formal analysis a Wei Hong Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization a ⁎ Shuguang Deng Formal analysis c Jun Wang Resources Funding acquisition a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanchang University, Nanchang 330031, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Nanchang University Nanchang 330031 PR China aSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanchang University, Nanchang 330031, PR China b School of Resources and Environmental, Nanchang University, Nanchang 330031, PR China School of Resources and Environmental Nanchang University Nanchang 330031 PR China bSchool of Resources and Environmental, Nanchang University, Nanchang 330031, PR China c School for Engineering of Matter, Transport and Energy, Arizona State University, AZ 85287, USA School for Engineering of Matter Transport and Energy Arizona State University AZ 85287 USA cSchool for Engineering of Matter, Transport and Energy, Arizona State University, AZ 85287, USA ⁎ Corresponding authors. Herein, a novel and flexible self-supporting gas diffusion electrode (GDE) was fabricated, which including an electrodeposited Bi nanocomposite as a catalyst layer and MIL-101 derived porous carbon in the gas diffusion layer (GDL). Compared with the conventional fabrication of GDE electrodes, the electrodeposition approach can avoid the tedious drop-casting processes of the catalyst layer (CL). The in situ growth mode by electrodeposition can also ensure the firmly interaction between CL and current collector, thus enhancing the stability of the electrode. Meanwhile, the porous carbon derived from MIL-101 which with a high specific area is conducive for the CO2 enrichment on the electrode, thus facilitate the reaction with high current density. Owe to the special structure, the resultant catalyst showed excellent performance for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) with enhanced formic acid generation. Notably, at -1.37 V (vs. RHE), a large current density of 400 mA cm-2 and a high formate Faraday efficiency (FEformate) of 96.5 % were achieved, and the yield of formic acid reached 46.5 mmol cm-2 h-1, which is superior to most electrocatalytic catalysts for CO2RR. In addition, the FEformate value remained high (>90 %) over a wide voltage window of 800 mV, and the catalyst also maintained stable operation at industrial current density for 70 h. This work provides a new strategy for the design of GDEs with novel structure to achieve high activity and durability for different electrocatalysis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Electrocatalytic reduction Gas diffusion electrode Electrodeposition Formic acid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The conversion of CO2 into high value-added products opens up a sustainable and technologically feasible path to alleviate the global environmental problems caused by the excessive emission of the greenhouse gas CO2 [1–3]. In this term, electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) is regarded as a promising strategy to convert CO2 into various products [4–6]. Among the products of CO2RR, formic acid has received special attention, because of that formic acid is an important raw chemical that widely used in the field of drug manufacturing and also can be acted as an excellent energy storage material in fuel cell technology [7]. Amongst the exploration of various catalysts for formate synthesis, Bi-based catalysts have attracted much attention within the field of electrocatalytic CO2RR due to its non-toxic and environmentally friendly properties [8–15]. To date, a number of Bi-based electrocatalysts have been successfully developed and demonstrated relatively high selectivity for formate generation [12]. Nevertheless, most of these Bi-based catalysts are either limited by too negative and narrowly applied potentials or low current density, which rendering these catalysts still far from the real industrial applications with high current density (over 200 mA cm-2). The construction of economic feasible and high-performance CO2RR electrocatalysts for the formate generation with large current density are still urgently needed. Except the electrocatalyst synthesis, the rational design of the electrode structure also offers an effective approach to achieve high current density for CO2RR. Generally, the CO2RR electrodes are fabricated by mixing the electrocatalysts with polymer binders and superconductive additives as inks and then coating them on carbon substrate [13]. However, this typical drop-casting electrode fabrication approach often leads to a limited durability, since the interaction between catalysts composite and current collectors is weak. After long-term electrochemical operation, the catalysts are prone to detach from the current collectors. Besides, although conductive additives such as Ketjenblack carbon or acetylene black are employed to enhance the conductivity of the electrodes, while its limited active surface area and uncontrolled interfaces are count against the formate generation with high current density [14]. In this term, in situ electrodeposition of Bi metallic nanocomposite onto a conductive support such as carbon cloth as a binder-free electrode can be an effective way to alleviate this problem due to several merits, i) the deposition conditions of catalysts prepared by electrodeposition are convenient and easy to operate, which can avoid the multiple tedious catalyst coating processes; ii) the microstructure and loading density of the catalyst can be easily controlled; iii) the catalysts prepared by electrodeposition are tightly grow on the substrate with good homogeneity without the need of a binder such as Nafion, which is benefit to accelerate the electron transfer during the electrocatalysis [15–17]. Therefore, controllable electrodeposition of a Bi nanocomposite to the current collectors can avoid the addition of polymer binders and superconductive additives, which maybe provides an effective path to achieve an enhanced CO2RR durability. On the other hand, the electrochemical cells used for CO2RR are also affect the electrochemical performance. The typical CO2RR H-cell electrolytic cells generally afford low current density, while large current density is difficult to achieved due to the limited mass transport of CO2. In contrast, the use of gas diffusion electrodes (GDE) with a catalyst layer deposited on a porous hydrophobic gas diffusion layer (GDL) in a flow-through electrolytic cell with CO2 as the gas feeder shortens the diffusion length to a few tens of nanometers and can provide currents greater than 1 A cm-2 [18]. Generally, the GDL is composed of a gas diffusion substrate and a microporous layer (MPL) such as carbon paper [19,20]. However, this type of GDE easily suffers from electrolyte leaching within a few hours resulting in flooding that affects the catalytic performance during CO2RR [21]. Accordingly, there are few attempts to stabilize GDL for CO2RR applications and improving the stability of GDE against flooding with terminal fluorosilanes or functionalized catalysts with PTFE nanoparticles dispersed within the catalyst layer [22,23]. Another option is the use of PTFE GDE, which can stabilize the liquid flow cell operation for >100 h [21,24]. Unfortunately, this method requires the sputtering a thick layer of metallic catalysts such as silver, copper and gold in order to enhance electron transfer, which limits the application of catalysts that cannot be sputtered or with low conductivity. In addition, the improvement of MPL in GDL is also beneficial to improve the performance of the catalyst, MPL plays an important role in the electrode to adjust the pore structure of the electrode and modulate the mass transfer performance of the electrode. The common microporous layer is composed of carbon black and hydrophobic agent materials such as PTFE [25–27]. Compared with the common carbon black, metal-organic-framework (MOF) derived porous carbon, such as MIL-101 derived carbon owns a relatively large specific surface area and its chemical composition is rich with nitrogen, which is conducive to CO2 enrichment and improve the performance of the catalyst during electrocatalysis [28–30]. However, the use of MIL-101 derived carbon in the GDL for CO2RR is still rare. Herein, we fabricated a GDE which including the electrodeposition of Bi nanocomposite on self-supporting carbon cloth as the catalyst layer and MIL-101-derived porous carbon in the GDL. Electrochemical measurement results show that the prepared GDE delivers an excellent performance for CO2RR to generate formate. Remarkably, the GDE affords a high current density of 400 mA cm-2 and a FEformate of 96.5 % at −1.37 V (RHE). The yield of formate reaches 46.5 mmol cm-2 h-1, which is faster than most catalysts for the CO2RR to formate. It is worth noting that in the wide voltage window of 800 mV, the FEformate maintains at a high value (>90 %). Due to the strong interaction between the Bi nanocomposite and current collector, the catalyst can also maintain stable operation for 70 h under the industrial required current density (200 mA cm-2), indicating its good stability. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Carbon cloth (CC, WOS1011) was purchased from Suzhou Shengeruo Technology Co. Hydrochloric acid, Bi(NO3)3∙5H2O, AlCl3∙6H2O, 2-aminobenzene dicarboxylic acid (NH2-H2BDC) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co. 60 wt% PTFE emulsion (POLYFLON PTFE D-210C, Daikin, Japan, nonionic surfactant: polyoxyethene glycol alkyl ether < 5 %) and carbon black (CB, Vulcan XC-72, USA) were commercially supplied by a local company. Ethanol (C2H5OH) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. All chemicals used in the experiments were of analytical grade (AR) without additional purifications. Carbon dioxide (99.999 %) and argon (99.999 %) were purchased from Nanchang Guoteng Gas Co. 2.2 Catalysts synthesis and electrode preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of MIL-101 derived carbon NH2−MIL-101 (Al) was prepared according to the methodology described in the literature [30]. 0.51 g of AlCl3∙6H2O was dissolved in 30 mL of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and stirred after ultrasonication for 30 min to ensure complete dissolution. Subsequently, 0.56 g of NH2-H2BDC was added to this AlCl3∙6H2O solution and again sonicated for 15 min. Next, the mixed solution was transferred to a Teflon autoclave reactor and heated at a constant temperature of 130 °C for 70 h. The resulting yellow precipitate after solvent-thermal reaction was collected by centrifugation and washed three times with DMF and ethanol, respectively, and finally dried under vacuum at 120 °C overnight. For the carbonization, certain amount of the as-synthesized NH2-MIL-101 (Al) was placed in a ceramic crucible and heated to 900 °C under nitrogen atmosphere at a ramp rate of 5 °C min-1 and kept at this temperature for five hours. Upon completion of the heat treatment, the furnace was cooled to room temperature in a nitrogen atmosphere. The resultant black powder samples were treated by immersing them in a dilute hydrochloric acid solution at 80 °C overnight to remove the Al/Al oxides. The black product was collected by centrifugation and washed repeatedly with deionized water and ethanol until the washing solution was neutral, and followed by vacuum drying. The final MIL-101 (Al)-derived carbon was denoted as MDC hereafter. 2.2.2 Fabrication of Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P The CC was pretreated by washing in 0.1 mol l-1 hydrochloric acid, ethanol, and deionized water for 30 min. The cleaned CC was dried in an oven at 60 °C, and then used for Bi electroplating. Bi nanocomposite was deposited on the carbon cloth using an electrolytic cell with graphite and carbon rod electrodes as counter electrodes and reference electrodes respectively. During the electrodeposition, the CC was used as the cathode, and one side of the CC is directly facing the counter electrode, thus ensure the uniform deposition of Bi nanocomposite at this side. To electrodeposit a dense Bi composite on CC, a constant current technique was used with a current of 10 mA for 24 h in a solution containing 0.1 mol l-1 of Bi(NO3)3∙5H2O and 1 mol l-1 of nitric acid. Then, the CC electrodeposited with Bi nanocomposite was coated with a gas diffusion layer. Specifically, PTFE was diluted with water to form an emulsion with a mass fraction of 30 wt %. After that, 2 mL of the emulsion was mixed with 20 mg of MDC and ultrasonically stirred for 2 h to obtain the mixed slurry. A spray gun connected with nitrogen was used to spray the mixed slurry (MDC and PTFE) onto one side of CC, namely the opposite side which Bi nanocomposite was deposited. After dried with an infrared lamp, the GDE was sintered in a tube furnace for 1 h (air sintering, 260 °C), the resultant GDE was denoted as Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P. 2.2.3 Fabrication of comparison GDE electrodes Bi/Bi2O3-CC-CB/P: The electrode was prepared in the same way as that for Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P, except that the MDC powder in the mixed slurry was replaced by carbon black. Bi2O3-CC-P: The electrode was prepared by removing the MDC powder in the mixed emulsion, only sprayed PTFE emulsion. Other steps were the same as Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P electrode. CC-M/P: The electrode was fabricated with pure carbon cloth, other prpreparation processes were same as Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P. Bi-CP: The electrode was prepared by electrodeposited Bi nanocomposite on carbon paper, the deposition conditions were the same as Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P. 2.3 Characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected on PANalytical's Empyrean Series 2 equipment (The Netherlands) using a Cu Kα ray source. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (ESCALAB 250Xi) was used, and the XPS tests were carried out utilizing monochromatic Al Kα as the excitation source. Raman spectral data were obtained on a HR 800 confocal Raman spectrometer equipped with multiple laser emission sources at 633, 473, 532 and 785 nm. The adsorption-desorption isotherms of nitrogen were determined using an ASAP 2460 analyzer (USA) at 77 K temperature and nitrogen atmosphere. The morphological characteristics of the samples were analyzed by a cold field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Regulus 8100, Japan) and a transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100, Japan). 2.4 Electrochemical measurements All electrochemical tests were performed in a specially designed three-electrode, two-compartment cell system with an electrochemical workstation. The system was based on a flow-cell structure, in which the two reaction chambers were separated by an anion-exchange membrane. The electrodes were including Hg/HgO as the reference electrode and IrO2/Ti (area 2 × 2 cm2) as the counter electrode, and the electrolyte was a 1 mol L-1 KOH solution. Prior to the electrochemical experiment, CO2 or Ar gas was pre-purged for 30 min, and the gas flow rate was maintained at 20 mL min-1 to ensure that the cathode chamber was fully saturated with gas. The potential values were all converted to reversible hydrogen electrode potential (RHE) according to the equation, E (V vs. RHE) = E (V vs. Hg/HgO) + 0.098 V + 0.0592 × pH. Before the CO2RR measurements, the GDE was selectively electrochemical activated by cyclic voltammetry with a potential range of −1 to 0 V for 1 h. The gas products detection were carried out with a gas chromatography, in which H2 and CO were analyzed by a Haysep Q column coupled with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The hydrocarbons were analyzed by an alumina column with a flame ionization detector (FID). For the analysis of the liquid phase products, a water suppression strategy was applied with the aid over a Bruker Avance 400 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer (1H NMR). 3 Results and discussion The fabrication procedures of GDE are present in Fig. 1 a. Briefly, a Bi-based nanocomposite was electrodeposited onto a self-supported CC with a constant current technique. The side of CC which face to the counter electrode was deposited with a Bi nanocomposite with high density. To prepare the GDL, the MIL-101 precursor was prepared. The successful synthesis of MIL-101 (Al) was confirmed by XRD analysis (Fig. S1). After the carbonization and removal of the Al/Al oxides, the MIL-101 derived carbon (MDC) was obtained. XRD and EDS analyses have verified the successful preparation of MDC without remaining Al/Al oxides [30] (Figs. S2, S3). Subsequently, the opposite side of the CC with high-dense Bi nanocomposite was sprayed with a mixture containing MDC and PTFE as the GDL. The detailed procedures have been provided in the experimental section. The resultant GDE that with the MDC and PTFE in the GDL was denoted as Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P. For comparison, the GDEs that without adding MDC in the GDL was denoted as Bi2O3-CC-P, and the GDE that replaced MDC with commercial CB in the GDL was denoted as Bi/Bi2O3-CC-CB/P, respectively. Fig. 1b describes the typical structure of the Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P. The GDE containing GDL and catalyst layer (CL). The as-fabricated Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P is consisted of PTFE and MDC as the GDL, along with as electrodeposited Bi nanocomposite as the CL. The special structure of this GDE is helpful for CO2RR with high current density. The morphology and structure of Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P were initially characterized with SEM. The morphology of the Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P before CO2RR shows dense microblocks (Fig. 2 a), which is obviously different compared with the pristine CC (Fig. S4). To investigate the morphology evolution during electrocatalysis, the Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P after an electro-activation was also examined as illustrated in Fig. 2b. The result demonstrates that the Bi nanocomposite on the CC was in situ reconstructed to form uniformly nanosheets with high density (Fig. 2b) after an electrochemical activation [31,32]. The structural changes of the Bi nanocomposite were also carefully characterized by TEM. Fig. 2c and d illustrate the bulk structure of the Bi nanocomposite scraped from the Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P without electrochemical activation. It can be observed that there are some surface defects in the Bi nanocomposite, which originated from the heat treatment during the catalyst fabrication process [33,34]. In contrast, it can be noticed that the morphology of the Bi nanocomposite was transformed into nanosheets structure (Fig. 2e) after the electrochemical activation. High-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) (Fig. 2f) shows that the lattice spaces of Bi nanocomposite are 0.32 nm and 0.23 nm, which corresponding to the Bi2O3 (012) planes and the (110) planes of the rhombic Bi [34,35] respectively. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and elemental mappings suggest that Bi and O were uniformly distributed throughout the Bi nanocomposite structure (Fig. 2g). The Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P samples were further analyzed with XRD. As shown in Fig. 3 a, there are typical diffraction peaks that assigned to Bi and Bi2O3 can be observed [36]. To further investigate the valency states of the catalysts, XPS spectra were collected. Fig. 3b shows the full XPS survey spectrum, which confirms the presence of Bi and O elements in the catalyst. This result indicating the presence of Bi oxides in the catalyst again. Meanwhile, there are two sets of visible peaks both for the Bi elemental before and after electrochemical activation (Fig. 3c), of which the peak pair located at ca. 156.8 and 162.2 eV belongs to Bi0, and the other peak pair centered at ca. 158.0 and 163.3 eV belongs to Bi3+ [36]. The O1s peak of Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P (Fig. 3d) shows an obvious peak at around 529.2 eV, which corresponding to the Bi-O bond. 3.1 Electrochemical measurements of the CO2RR The CO2RR performance of Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P GDE was evaluated by an alkaline flow cell. Linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) was used to test the catalytic activity of Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P for CO2RR in 1 mol l-1 KOH electrolyte with saturated CO2/Ar over a potential range of 0 ∼ −4 V vs. RHE. The scanning rate was 10 mV s-1. All potentials mentioned hereafter are relative to the RHE. Notably, the current density in CO2-saturated electrolyte is larger than that in Ar-saturated electrolyte (Fig. 4 a), indicating that the catalyst owns noticeable electrocatalytic activity for CO2RR. The electrocatalytic CO2RR performance of Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P catalyst was evaluated at different cathodic potentials (Fig. 4b). The liquid-phase product is purely consisted of formate as verified by the 1H NMR (Fig. S5) [37], while the gas-phase products are H2 and CO. Impressively, The FEformate maintains at about 95 % throughout the potential range (Fig. 4b), indicating its high selectivity for the formate generation. Meanwhile, the current density increases with more negative potential, and the current density can reach the industrial application level of 200 mA cm-2 at a potential of −0.97 V, and 400 mA cm-2 at a potential of −1.37 V along with a FEformate of 96 %. The performance of the catalyst for CO2 reduction was also tested in a constant current mode (Fig. 4c), and it was also seen that the FEformate was up to 96.5 % at a current of 400 mA, and that ca. 80 % formate was obtained at a current value of 1 A. The operating potential window for generation of formate with high FE (>90 %) in our catalyst is very wide (800 mV) (Fig. 4c). The rate of formate production increased with the potential changed to more negative, which reaching 46.5 mmol cm-2 h-1 at a potential of −1.37 V (Fig. 4d), this value is also significantly better than most of the reported electrocatalysts for formate generation (Table S1). In order to verify the role of MDC in the GDL, other catalysts (Bi/Bi2O3-CC-CB/P, Bi/Bi2O3-CC-P, Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P) were also tested for performance comparison (Fig. 4e). Similarly, LSV tests were conducted to initially analyze the CO2RR activity (Fig. S6). The lower current density of Bi/Bi2O3-CC-P than that of the Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P suggest its lower CO2RR activity (Fig. S6). Further investigations reveal that the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) over these catalysts is more serious (Fig. S7) comparing with the Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P. The results prove that the Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P owns the best performance for the production of formate, while the Bi/Bi2O3-CC-P and Bi/Bi2O3-CC-CB/P are less effective for formate generation (Fig. S6). These results demonstrate that the different carbons used in the GDL will influence the CO2RR performance. In this regard, the specific surface area of the experimentally prepared MDC and the CB used were measured with N2 adsorption/desorption approach (Fig. S8). The results show that the prepared MDC has a larger specific surface area than the CB, which is more favorable for the regulating CO2 enrichment and diffusion during the electrocatalysis. Moreover, the nitrogen in the MDC is also beneficial for the CO2 enrichment at the electrode, which is more conducive to achieving efficient reaction with high current density. As a self-supporting substrate, the CC also played an important role during the electrocatalysis. In comparison, the performance of Bi-CP catalyst which used carbon paper (CP) instead was also prepared and tested for CO2RR (Fig. S9). The research results indicate that using CC as the substrate for electrodes is more conducive to electrodeposit more active sites of Bi nanocomposites, thus more favorable for CO2RR. The CO2RR performances of the electrode are also better than most of the recent reported state-of-art catalysts at an exceed industrially required current densities (400 mA cm-2) (Fig. 4f, and Table S1). The above results clearly demonstrate the excellent performance and high selectively formate generation of the developed materials for CO2RR. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) is related to the number of active sites and proportional to the double layer capacitance (Cdl) value of the electrode [38]. For this reason, cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements were performed over different catalysts at various scan rates (20–100 mV s-1) (Fig. S10). The results show that the Cdl of Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P is 13.7 mF cm-2 (Fig. 5 a), which is higher than that of other catalysts, suggesting its more active sites. Stability at industrially required current densities (200 mA cm-2) is also critical important for practical CO2RR application [10,39]. During the test, the Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P remained stable for >70 h at a current density of 200 mA cm-2, with a formate selectivity higher than 95 % (Fig. 5b). The catalyst after long-term stability testing was characterized by SEM and TEM, as shown in Fig. S11. The results showed no obvious changes, indicating the good stability of the catalyst. The CO2RR intermediates was then studied by in situ Raman spectroscopy. Fig. 6 a shows the in situ Raman spectra of the prepared catalyst (Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P). Three distinct peak groups are observed. The peak at 1007 cm⁻1 corresponds to HCO₃⁻, 1065 cm⁻¹ to CO₃²⁻. Notably, the peak at 1350 cm⁻¹ represents the formate intermediate (Vs(o-c-o)) [40–43]. The intensities of these three peaks significantly increased with more negative potentials. Additionally, in situ Raman spectra of two other catalysts (Bi/Bi2O3-CC-CB/P, Bi/Bi2O3-CC-P) were also measured as shown in Fig. 6b and c. Similar intermediate peaks can also be observed. However, its intensities are notably weaker compared to those of catalyst (Bi/Bi2O3-CC-M/P). This result indicates that by using MDC in GDL can enhance the catalytic performance of GDE. The improvement is attributed to the larger specific surface area of MDC compared to carbon black, which is beneficial for the CO2 enrichment as well the mass transfer, thus promoting the catalytic processes. 4 Conclusions In summary, a GDE was prepared by electrodeposition of Bi nanocomposite on a self-supporting CC and combined with MIL-101(Al)-derived porous carbon in the GDL. The large surface area of CC allows the electrodeposition of Bi nanocomposite with high density. Different from the traditional electrode catalyst layers preparation, the electrodeposition method avoids the tedious drop-casting procedures. The in situ growth of electrocatalyst layer by electrodeposition can also effectively improve the tightness between the catalyst and the current collector, thereby enhancing the stability of the catalyst. Meanwhile, by using the MIL-101 derived carbon in the GDL is helpful for the enrichment of the CO2 at the electrode, thus increase the current density. Own to the special structure of the electrode, the resultant material developed herein show an excellent performance for formate the generation form CO2RR. Specifically, at −1.37 V vs. RHE, a large current density of 400 mA cm-2 and a FEformate of 96.5 % were achieved, and the rate of formate yield reached 46.5 mmol cm-2h-1, which is significantly better than most state-of-the-art electrocatalysts. Moreover, the FEformate values remained high (>90 %) over a wide voltage window of 800 mV. In addition, the electrode was able to maintain stable operation for 70 h at an industrial required current density of 200 mA cm-2. This study provides a new strategy for the preparation of new advanced GDE that can be extended to the development of other metal catalysts for highly stable, efficient and active CO2RR as well as other energy storage and conversion reactions, such as the electroreduction of the O2/N2 reaction. coredata.dc:description: Herein, a novel and flexible self-supporting gas diffusion electrode (GDE) was fabricated, which including an electrodeposited Bi nanocomposite as a catalyst layer and MIL-101 derived porous carbon in the gas diffusion layer (GDL). Compared with the conventional fabrication of GDE electrodes, the electrodeposition approach can avoid the tedious drop-casting processes of the catalyst layer (CL). The in situ growth mode by electrodeposition can also ensure the firmly interaction between CL and current collector, thus enhancing the stability of the electrode. Meanwhile, the porous carbon derived from MIL-101 which with a high specific area is conducive for the CO2 enrichment on the electrode, thus facilitate the reaction with high current density. Owe to the special structure, the resultant catalyst showed excellent performance for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) with enhanced formic acid generation. Notably, at -1.37 V (vs. RHE), a large current density of 400 mA cm-2 and a high formate Faraday efficiency (FEformate) of 96.5 % were achieved, and the yield of formic acid reached 46.5 mmol cm-2 h-1, which is superior to most electrocatalytic catalysts for CO2RR. In addition, the FEformate value remained high (>90 %) over a wide voltage window of 800 mV, and the catalyst also maintained stable operation at industrial current density for 70 h. This work provides a new strategy for the design of GDEs with novel structure to achieve high activity and durability for different electrocatalysis.
